seg.output: Letter to Rudolph Asper concerning writing matters. To the distinguished man Rudolph Asper, my most sincere friend Volcatius. Greetings. I could certainly not complain about you, who have suddenly become very lukewarm from being a very passionate friend. What is it that you desire of me? What venerable bond has been broken? Who is the author of this unjust divorce? Who is so wicked, so nefarious, and so impious? What language is so venomous and deadly? May the Lord destroy all deceitful lips! What can't an evil tongue do? What, I pray, are you neglecting? I beg you, if anything is going on that is contrary to your spirit, indicate it, and don't believe the insane cries and the mendacious webs spun everywhere. You know until this day the bad demons, the envious men, and the hostile ones to friendship. If you desire anything of me, here I am, here you have an old friend and more than an old Volcatius, indeed an old Anius, for you will not find a Polymnestor in me.

seg.output: I could not certainly complain of you with injustice, who suddenly turned from an ardent friend to an extremely lukewarm one. What is it that you desire from me? What venerable bond was broken? What is the author of this unjust divorce? Who is so wicked, so nefarious, and so impious? What language is so virulent and deadly? May the Lord disperse all deceitful lips! What can't an impious tongue do? What, I pray, do you neglect? I beseech you, if there is anything being done contrary to your nature, point it out and do not give your faith to the senseless cries and mendacious stories coming from all sides. You have known to this day wicked demons, envious men, and enemies of friendship. If you desire anything of me, lo, I am here, behold, you have an old friend, and more than an old Volcatius, nay, an old Anius; for you will not find a Polymnestor in me. Arsocomas, a man of the Scythian people before the King of the Bosporus, Leucanor, speaking of great riches, said: “I have no wagons, nor cattle, but I have two honest and just friends, such as no other Scythian has.” He was thinking of Macentas and Lonchates. The event itself showed how much power the true friendship of these two had; for it was so great that it exceeded royal power and conquered immense wealth.

seg.output: I could certainly not complain about you unjustly, who suddenly changed from an ardent friend to a rather lukewarm one. What is it that you desire from me? What venerable bond has been broken? Who is the author of this unjust divorce? Who is so wicked, so nefarious and so impious? What language is so virulent and deadly? May the Lord destroy all deceitful lips! What can't an evil tongue do? What, I pray, do you neglect? I beg you, if there is something that is foreign to your soul, indicate it and don't give credit to any insane clamors and fabrications from all sides. You have known until this day wicked demons, envious men and those who are hostile to friendship out of envy. If you desire anything from me, here I am, here you have an old friend and more than an old Volcatius, yes, an old Anius, for you won't find a Polymnestor in me. Arsocomas, a plebeian man from the Scythian people, was speaking before King Leucanor of Bosporus about great riches: "I have neither carts nor herds," he said, "but I have two honest and upright friends, like no others among the Scythians". He was thinking of Macentas and Lonchates. The outcome of the matter itself showed what power the true friendship of two had. So powerful in all things is true friendship that it surpasses royal power and conquers great riches. Therefore, it is certain that the same was not less between us. Let Amizos and Dandamis go away, let Blitte and Blasthenes depart; what then could I not complain about this sudden misfortune? Nisus Vergilianus thought he had lost his life when Eurialus was killed; and could I have believed I could live safely with my own Eurialus estranged?

seg.output: I could certainly not complain of you with injustice, who suddenly became very lukewarm from an ardent friend. What is it that you desire from me? What venerable bond has been broken? Who is the author of such an unjust divorce? Who is so wicked, so nefarious, and so impious? What language is so virulent and deadly? May the Lord disperse all deceitful lips! What cannot an impious tongue do? What, I pray, do you neglect? I beseech you, if there is anything that is carried out contrary to your mind, indicate it, and do not wish to give faith to the insane clamors and the lies woven everywhere. You know that up to this day evil demons, envious men, and hostile to friendship have envied it. If you desire anything from me, I am ready, here you have again an old friend and more than the old Volcatius, rather the old Anius, for you will not find the mind of Polymnestor in me. This Arsocomas, a plebeian of the Scythians, was speaking before the king Leucanor of the Bosporus concerning great riches: "I have neither chariots nor herds," he said, "but I have two honest and respectable friends, such as the other Scythians have none". He was thinking of Macentas and Lonchates. The issue of the matter showed how much strength true friendship had. So powerful in all things is true friendship, that it surpasses royal power, and overcomes the greatest riches. This, then, has been no less mutual between us. Let Amizoces and Dandamis go away, let Blitte and Blasthenes retire; what then should I not complain of this sudden misfortune? Nisus the Vergilian thought he had lost his life when he killed Eurialus; and should I believe I could live securely with my other Eurialus estranged? The small matters of Cicero, Valerius, and Lucian are compared to ours! - But what am I carried away by grief, meditating on far different things, if perhaps, by the propitious favor of God, the ashes or sparks of ancient friendship could be restored, repaired, and revived!

I could surely complain of an injustice done to me, since you suddenly changed from an ardent friend to a very lukewarm one. What is it, that you are missing in me? What has broken such a venerable bond? Who is the author of this so unjust divorce? Who is so wicked, so nefarious and so impious? What language is so venomous and deadly? May the Lord destroy all deceitful lips! What can't an impious tongue do? What, I pray, do you complain of being neglected? I beg you, if there is anything being done contrary to your will, indicate it and don't give your faith to any insane shouts and lies woven together from all sides. You know that until now bad demons, envious men and hostile to friendship have envied. If you have any desire in me, here I am, you have an old friend and more than an old Volcatius, even an old Anius, for you won't find a Polymnestor in me. Arsocomas, a plebeian man of the Scythians, was debating with Leucanor, the king of the Bosporus, about great wealth: “I possess neither wagons nor herds, but I have two honest and trustworthy friends, such as none of the Scythians have", he said. He was thinking of Macentas and Lonchates. But the outcome of the matter itself showed how much strength there was in the true friendship of the two. So powerful is true friendship in all things, that it surpasses royal power and conquers the greatest wealth. It is obvious, therefore, that this was no less a mutual one between us. Let Amizoces and Dandamidis go, let Blitte and Blasthenes depart; what therefore should I not complain of this sudden misfortune? Nisus the Virgilian thought he had lost his life when Eurialus was slain; and shall I not think myself secure in living when my own Eurialus is alienated from me? The sayings of Cicero, Valerius and Lucian are nothing in comparison to ours! - But whither does my grief carry me meditating on far other things, if, by God's favour, the ashes or sparks of our ancient friendship could be restored and raised again! And, if I have not too little faith in God, I shall still hold your friendship, especially yours, as sacred with me.

I know that opinions about me and my actions vary widely. If these opinions were to be brought to light, they would likely cause me more enmity than friendship, more discord than peace, and would be fabricated by the most wicked people, who are more devoted to the devil than to Christ. He has always been the author of murder and lies, while the latter is the source of truth and peace. I wish that everyone possessed the same spirit that I wish for myself. To prove my innocence and the injustice of your hatred towards me, I will talk briefly with you, so that you may recognize my intentions. I am sure that Hercules, if he were to act as judge, would not reject my claims. If he knows something better, I beseech and implore him, through Christian charity, the symbol of baptism, and whatever remains of old friendship, to act in the place of my teacher. In the meantime, I am sure that no wise or good man would oppose my efforts.
So far we have spent a good portion of our time studying those decrees and decretals, as they are called, and the opinions of the most renowned people, not without considerable effort and, if I may say so, great tedium, because each one was attacking the decisions of the other and each one was overturning the decrees of the other. We have often argued, examined the opinions of all, and found contradictions, some appealing to Innocent, others to Nicholas. I have then turned my attention to the leading people in the Church and read and reflected upon them, but I have found them to be in disagreement, one determining one thing and another something else. The reading of Eusebius and Epiphanius will provide abundant testimony to this, and it is necessary to accept one side or the other. I have seen that their weapons are the Scriptures, the true Scriptures, the goal of the Scriptures.
Cyprian, that most eminent writer among the Greeks and Latins, bishop of Carthage and martyr, regulates all things according to the Scriptures. There is still extant a testimony of this in his first book of letters, letter 8, which reads in this manner: "Adultery is impious, sacrilegious, and whatever is done in human passion in violation of the divine arrangement." "Let no one, brethren, lead you astray from the way of the Lord, let no one snatch you away from the gospel of Christ" etc.

seg.output: Cyprian, the most eminent writer and bishop of Carthage, both among the Greeks and Latins, and a martyr, thinks that all should be regulated according to scripture. There are still testimonies of this in his 1st book of letters, epistle 8, in this manner: "It is adultery, impious, sacrilegious, whatever is instituted by human madness, to violate the divine order." "Let no one, brethren, lead you astray from the way of the Lord, let no one rob you as Christians from the gospel of Christ" etc. And in book 2, epistle 3: "From that which the master Christ has commanded and done," he says, "we should not depart by human and new institutes." "We should not depart in any way from the evangelical precepts; and the same things which the master taught and did, the disciples ought to observe and do, more strongly and firmly, in another place the blessed apostle teaches, saying: "I marvel that you are so quickly removed from him who called you in the grace" etc. [Gal 1:6]. "And what Christ should be heard alone, the Father also testifies from heaven, saying: "This is my beloved son, in whom I am well pleased; hear him" [Mt 17:5]. Therefore, if Christ alone should be heard, we should not pay attention to what someone else before us thought should be done, but what the one before all, Christ, did first; for we should not follow the custom of man, but the truth of God, when through Isaiah the prophet God speaks and says: "But they honor me with their lips, but their heart is far from me, teaching for doctrines the commandments of men" [Isa 29:13].

seg.output: Cyprian, an eminent writer, bishop, and martyr from Carthage, among both the Greeks and the Latins, wishes everything to be according to scripture. His opinion is testified to in the first book of letters, letter 8, in these words: "It is adultery, it is impious, it is sacrilege, whatever is ordained by human madness, that the divine order be violated." "Let no one, brothers, lead you astray from the way of the Lord, let no one snatch you away from the gospel of Christ" etc. And in the second book of letters, letter 3: "From that which Christ, the teacher, both commanded and did," he says, "we must not depart by any human and new institution." "We must not in any way depart from the evangelical precepts; and the same which the teacher taught and did his disciples ought to observe and do, the blessed apostle teaches more firmly and more strongly in another place, saying: "I marvel that you are so quickly removed from him who called you into grace" [Gal 1:6]. "And that Christ should alone be heard, the Father from heaven also bears witness, saying: "This is my beloved Son, in whom I am well pleased; hear ye him" [Mt 17:5]. Therefore, if only Christ should be heard, we must not consider what some have thought to be done before us, but what Christ, who is before all, has done first; for we ought not to follow the custom of man, but the truth of God, when God speaks through the prophet Isaiah, and says: "But they honor me with their lips, teaching for doctrines the commandments of men" [Isa 29:13]. And the same Lord in the gospel repeats and says: "Ye reject the commandment of God, that ye may keep your own tradition" [Mt 15:6; Mk 7:9]; but also in another place he puts and says: "Whosoever shall break one of these least commandments, and shall so teach men, he shall be called the least in the kingdom of God" [Mt 5:19]. "Now if we are priests of God and of Christ, I find none whom we ought to follow more than God and Christ, since he himself says in the gospel in the highest degree: "I am the light of the world; he that follows me shall not walk in darkness, but shall have the light of life.”

Quare, si solus Christus audiendus est, non debemus attendere, quid aliquis ante nos faciendum putaverit, sed quid, qui ante omnes est, Christus prior fecerit; neque enim hominis consuetudinem sequi oportet, sed dei veritatem, cum per Isaiam prophetam deus loquatur et dicat: «Sine caussa autem colunt me, mandata ad doctrinas hominum docentes» [Jes 29,13]. Et idem dominus in evangelio repetat et dicat: «Reiicitis mandatum dei, ut traditionem vestram statuatis» [Mt 15,6; Mk 7,9]; sed et in alio loco ponit et dicit: «Qui solverit unum ex mandatis istis minimis et sic docuerit homines, minimus vocabitur in regno dei» [Mt 5,19]. «Iam si sacerdotes dei et Christi sumus, non invenio, quem magis sequi quam deum et Christum debeamus, cum ipse in evangelio maxime dicat: «Ego sum lumen mundi; qui me sequtus fuerit, non ambulabit in tenebris, sed habebit lumen vitae». Ne ergo in tenebris ambulemus, Christum sequi et praecepta eius observare debemus, quia et ipse alio in loco mittens apostolos dixit: «Data est mihi potestas omnis in coelo et in terra» etc. [Mt 28,18]. Et idem dominus in evangelio repetat et dicat: «Reiicitis mandatum dei, ut traditionem vestram statuatis» [Mt 15,6; Mk 7,9]; sed et in alio loco ponit et dicit: «Qui solverit unum ex mandatis istis minimis et sic docuerit homines, minimus vocabitur in regno dei» [Mt 5,19]. «Iam si sacerdotes dei et Christi sumus, non invenio, quem magis sequi quam deum et Christum debeamus, cum ipse in evangelio maxime dicat: «Ego sum lumen mundi; qui me sequtus fuerit, non ambulabit in tenebris, sed habebit lumen vitae». seg.output: Cyprian, the most eminent writer among the Greeks and Latins from Carthage, bishop and martyr, wants everything to be in accordance with scripture. There are still testimonies of this in the 1st book of letters, letter 8, in this way: "Adultery is impious, sacrilegious, and whatever is established by human madness, so that divine disposition is violated." "Let no one, brethren, make you err from the way of the Lord, let no one take you away from the gospel of Christ", etc. And in the 2nd book, letter 3: "From what the teacher Christ both commanded and did," he says, "we must not depart from human and new institutions." "We must not at all depart from the evangelical precepts; and the same which the teacher taught and did, the blessed apostle teaches more firmly and strongly in another place, saying: "I marvel that ye are so quickly removed from him that called you into the grace of Christ" etc. [Gal 1:6]. "And that Christ alone should be heard, the Father also from heaven testifies, saying: "This is my beloved Son, in whom I am well pleased; hear ye him" [Mt 17:5]. Therefore, if Christ alone should be heard, we must not consider what anyone before us thought should be done, but what Christ, who is before all, had done first; for we must not follow the custom of man, but the truth of God, when God speaks through the prophet Isaiah and says: "But they honour me with their lips; but their heart is far from me; but in vain do they worship me, teaching for doctrines the commandments of men" [Jes 29:13]. And the same Lord repeats in the gospel and says: "Ye have rejected the commandment of God, that ye may keep your own tradition" [Mt 15:6; Mk 7:9]; but He also places it in another place and says: "Whosoever shall break one of these least commandments, and shall teach men so, shall be called least in the kingdom of heaven" [Mt 5:19]. "Now if we are priests of God and of Christ, I do not find whom we ought to follow more than God and Christ, since He Himself says most especially in the gospel: "I am the light of the world; he that followeth me shall not walk in darkness, but shall have the light of life" [Jn 8:12]. Therefore, that we may not walk in darkness, we must follow Christ and observe His precepts, for He also said in another place, sending His apostles: "All power is given unto me in heaven and in earth" [Mt 28:18]. "It is, therefore, suitable to our religion and fear, that we should keep the truth of the divine tradition, that when He shall come in His own brightness and celestial majesty, He may find us holding what He admonished, observing what He taught, doing what He did."

Cyprian, the most eminent writer among the Greeks and Latins from Carthage, bishop, and martyr, wants everything to be in accordance with Scriptures. There is still evidence of this in his First Book of Letters, letter 8, in this way: "It is adulterous, impious, sacrilegious, whatever is established by human frenzy, to violate the divine order". "Let no one, brothers, lead you astray from the way of the Lord, let no one snatch you away from the Gospel of Christ", etc. And book 2, letter 3: "We must not," he says, "deviate from what Christ, the teacher, commanded and did, by human and novel institutions". "We must not at all depart from the evangelical precepts; and the same that the teacher taught and did his disciples must also observe and do, the blessed apostle teaches more firmly and strongly in another place, saying: "I marvel that you are so quickly removed from him who called you into grace", etc. [Gal 1,6]. "And that Christ should be heard alone, the Father from heaven attests, saying: "This is my beloved Son, in whom I am well pleased; hear him" [Mt 17,5]. Therefore, if only Christ should be heard, we should not pay attention to what someone before us thought should be done, but what Christ, who is before all, did first; for we ought not to follow the custom of man, but the truth of God, when God speaks through Isaiah the prophet and says: "They worship me in vain, teaching doctrines of men" [Jes 29,13]. And the same Lord repeats in the Gospel and says: "You reject the commandment of God, to establish your tradition" [Mt 15,6; Mk 7,9]; but he also puts it in another place and says: "Whoever breaks one of these least commandments and teaches men so, he will be called the least in the kingdom of God" [Mt 5,19]. "Now, if we are priests of God and of Christ, I do not find whom we should follow more than God and Christ, since He Himself says in the Gospel most of all: "I am the light of the world; whoever follows me will not walk in darkness, but will have the light of life". So let us not walk in darkness, we must follow Christ and obey His precepts, because He also sent the apostles in another place and said: "All power has been given to me in heaven and on earth", etc. [Mt 28,18]. "Therefore, it is fitting for our religion and fear, that we keep the truth of the Lord's tradition, that He may find us holding on to what He warned us of, observing what He taught us, and doing what He did when He comes with His clarity and heavenly majesty". I pass over the letter written to Pompey against the letter of Stephen, in which he wants only Scriptures to be heard and teaches, at the end of the letter, in the manner of a channel, what the bishops of the Christian republic should do.
Augustine, no small doctor of the Church, does not want to be believed on his own, unless Scriptures are brought forth; he does not want to assent to fathers however learned and holy, unless Scriptures are brought forth. His open testimonies are to St. Jerome's letter, Casulanum, Fortunatus, and Vincentius, just as the author of the Decree of Gratianus records some traces in Dist. 9. Jerome, both the most eloquent and (to speak so) the most linguistically talented, excellently taught in Greek, Hebrew, and Latin, almost nothing asserts in his excellent work Commentary. seg.output: Augustinus, a great doctor of the church, does not believe himself unless he brings the scriptures; he does not want to agree with the fathers, however learned and holy they are, unless they bring the scriptures. His clear testimonies are the letter to St. Jerome, Casulanum, Fortunatus and Vincentius, as well as some traces recorded by the author of the Decree of Gratian, Dist. 9. Jerome, and eloquent and (so to speak) linguistically talented, learned in Greek, Hebrew and Latin, does not claim much in his best work, Commentary. Who does not know what a commentary sounds like? The Bishop of Poitiers, Hilary, wants to refer the sense from the scriptures, not to the scriptures. John Gerson, Chancellor of Paris: "It is rejected with the same facility with which it is proved that it has no authority from the Scriptures," he said. And time would fail me before I produced Chrysostom, Cyril, Gregory Nazianzen, Athanasius and the Greeks, Ambrose and Tertullian Latins. These, I say, conflicting, this handling of their scriptures, the example and imitation of these moved me to turn the sails from them also to the source of the sacred scriptures; for they too, did not they, confirm all their own with scriptures and tear them with scriptures? How much better, according to the voice of our Bernard, to drink from the sources themselves than from the streams? I think I have defended myself so far in this cause that you will not find much fault with my undertaking. I go on.

Quid mirum, si scripturas ardenti amore prosecutus sum?
When I went to the scriptures, I was amazed by the delight that filled my soul, all sweet, all smelling of ambrosia, no boredom, so that I thought I had found the complete voice of Christ in me 4 and 7. John ch. and no delay I found that it was in accordance with my business and the fathers: pseudoprophets were certainly not to be received, those who did not bring the word of the Lord, Deutero. 13 [1-5]. For there is a false prophet who does not bring the word of the Lord - John 10 [1]: "Whoever does not enter through the door is a thief and a robber"; Jeremiah 23 [21]: "I did not send them, yet they ran". Just like the prophets, sent and apostles, who went to the Word. Matthew 10 [41]: "Whoever receives a prophet in the name of a prophet" etc.c; Romans 10 [15]: "How then will they preach unless they are sent?" - Again nothing of human dream is to be added to the word of God, Deutero. 4 [2] and 12 [32], Proverbs 30 [6] standing only in the words of the Lord, Joshua 1 [7-8] and Psalm 1 [2]; only the word should be heard, Jeremiah 7 [23] and 23 [16ff]; sufficient this and nothing to be changed, Ezekiel 34 [11 ff]. - Why much? I go to the New Testament. Here Christ proves everything from the ancient scriptures, he wants to be known only from the scriptures, John 5 [39ff]; they recognize him from the scriptures, John 12 [16]. What wonder if I followed the scriptures with burning love?

As I continued to read the Scriptures, I was amazed at the delight that filled my heart, all sweet, all smelling of ambrosia, none against boredom, so that I judged myself to have a complete voice of Christ in 4 and 7 John chapters and without delay I found conformity [4,14; 7,38] to my task and to the fathers: that false prophets should not be accepted, those who do not bring the Lord's word, Deuteronomy 13 [1-5]. I go, I come to the New Testament. Here Christ proves everything with the ancient Scriptures, he wants to be known only by the Scriptures, John 5 [39ff]; his own recognize him from the Scriptures, John 12 [16]. The apostles confirm their Scriptures, as is evident in the Acts; all is regulated according to the Scriptures in Acts 15 [14-21]. Paul, "vessel of election" [Acts 9,15], always brings forth Scriptures. - Here I conclude: if the Son of God, who is the wisdom of the Father [1 Corinthians 1, 24], does nothing without the Scriptures, why do we still doubt to regulate everything according to the Scriptures?
In short: I find that the New Testament is nothing but the interpretation of the Old, except that it promises what this one teaches, that one is more hidden, this one more open, that one in wrappings and figures, this one in evident signs and in itself it acts.

Is it not evident, that the apostles spoke only from the scriptures, after they were enlightened by the Holy Ghost? Take the epistle of Paul to the Romans, and the method of the whole scripture, and you shall find the same summed up in a little compass; yet, if you find any thing contrary to the scriptures, I shall be mistaken. The same Paul, concluding this discourse, would have all things that are good to be kept, and commanded not to receive any human doctrines, 1 Tim. 6 [3-5.11], Titus 1 [13-14]; he forbids any thing to be added to his preaching, Galatians 1 [8].

Si nunc mihi irasci vellet genius tuus, age, irascatur scripturae et sanctis patribus, qui huc etiam quasi nolentem detrusere. Ceterum et hic inter saxum et sacrum herebam. Occurrit ilico: tibi soli fides? Scriptura multis est obvelata misteriis, ex patribus accipies scripturae sensum. Ac rursum ex adversa parte fortior mihi aries haec concutit hoc fragrore: eundem nimirum habet spiritum scriptura, quem a sui principio, licet igitur solis iis nos quoque operam collocare. Hoc enim constat primitivam ecclesiam non legisse Thomam, non Scotum, non Anthoninum, non Augustinum. Augustinum vero suam probasse intelligentiam ex scripturis iuxta verbum suum: Nullus est locus in scriptura tam obscurus, quin in alio loco explicetur. Et quoties invicem pugnant patres, ad scripturas concurrunt, certe ceu ad lucem; nam debent ignotiora per notiora demonstrari. Si vero tam obscura foret scriptura, ut sine Augustino intelligi non posset, obtectior esset Augustini scriptis. «Hoc autem admisso concedendum sanctos patres commentariis suis aliud non fecisse quam, dum sua probant scripturis, notiora probarint per ignotiora»; sed «quis ita insaniat»? An noluit spiritus sanctus intelligi et iis solum illabi, qui sapientes sunt et rabbini? Verum hic clamat Christus: «Gratias ago tibi, pater, domine coeli et terrae, quod absconderis haec a sapientibus et prudentibus, et revelaveris ea parvulis.» Et Tertullianus ait: «Ea est materia sapientiae secularis, temeraria interpraes divinae naturae dispositionis. Ipse denique haereses a phylosophia subornantur». «Fuerat Athenis» apostolus [Apg 17,16ff] et cetera. Et utinam tibi omnia ea adscribere possem! Est ergo verissima prophetae sententia: «Declaratio, ostium seu apertum verborum tuorum illuminat et intellectum dat parvulis» [Ps 119,130]. Lege hic Psalmum alphabeticum 118 et mira de hac re invenies. Rursus I. Ioan. 2 [27] scribitur: «Et non necesse habetis, ut quisquam doceat vos, sed sicut ipsa unctio docet vos de omnibus, et verax est et non mendatium, et sicut docuit vos, manete in ea.» Ubi audis spiritui dari intelligentiam, id, quod etiam promissum est Hieremie 31 [33-34], cui adsentitur Christus Ioan. 6 [43]: «Erunt omnes docti a deo.» Ita et Paulus: «Nos vero non spiritum mundi accepimus, sed spiritum, qui ex deo est, ut sciamus quae a Christo donata sint nobis. Quae et loquimur non sermonibus, quos docet humana sapientia, sed quos docet spiritus sanctus, spiritualibus spiritualia comparantes» [1Kor 2,12-13] etc.
seg.output: I continued; here I was rejoicing with the fruit of palms found, that with labors so easily overcome (by the fathers) as if through certain steps I had transcended to the height of things, and I saw from the testimony of Scripture and the Fathers that only the Scripture and one alone was sufficient and that it had no need of the human wit to be patched up. Thus I firmly set foot that only the Scripture was to be followed, being sufficient, without any human addition. If now your genius wanted to be angry with me, come, let him be angry with the Scripture and the holy Fathers, who even against my will have brought me here. But here is between a rock and a hard place. Immediately it occurs to me: faith to you alone? The Scripture is enveloped in many mysteries; from the Fathers you will receive the sense of the Scripture. And on the other side a stronger ram assaults me with this roar: that the Scripture has the same spirit, which from its beginning, although therefore let us also apply ourselves to those only. For it is certain that the primitive Church did not read Thomas, not Scotus, not Antoninus, not Augustine. But Augustine did approve of his understanding of the Scriptures according to his word: “There is no place in Scripture so obscure that it be not explained in another place.” And as often as the Fathers fight one another, they resort to the Scriptures, surely as to the light; for the more obscure are to be demonstrated by the more known. But if the Scripture were so obscure as not to be understood without Augustine, then it would be more concealed than by Augustine’s writings. “But this being granted, it must be allowed that the holy Fathers have done nothing in their commentaries but, while they approve their own by the Scriptures, prove the more known by the more obscure”; but “who is so mad?” Or did the holy spirit not want to be understood and only flow to those who are wise and rabbis? But here Christ cries out: “I thank thee, Father, Lord of heaven and earth, that thou hast hid these things from the wise and prudent, and hast revealed them unto babes.” And Tertullian says: “This is the matter of secular wisdom, rashly interpreting the divine order of nature. Indeed heresies themselves are suborned by philosophy.” “Paul was at Athens” [Acts 17:16ff] and the rest. And would that I could ascribe all this to you! Therefore the prophet’s sentence is most true: “The declaration of thy words giveth light, it giveth understanding unto the simple” [Ps 119:130]. Read here the alphabetic Psalm 118 and you will find wonderful things about it. Again it is written in 1 John 2 [27]: “And ye need not that any man teach you, but as the same anointing teacheth you of all things, and is truth, and is no lie, and even as it hath taught you, ye shall abide in it.” Where you hear that understanding is given to the spirit, that which is also promised in Jeremiah 31 [33-34], to which Christ agrees in John 6 [43]: “All shall be taught of God.” So also Paul: “For we have not received the spirit of the world, but the spirit which is of God, that we might know the things that are freely given to us of God. Which things also we speak, not in the words which man’s wisdom teacheth, but which the Holy Ghost teacheth, comparing spiritual things with spiritual” [1 Cor 2:12-13] etc.

seg.output: I continued; here upon finding the fruit of the palms I exulted with joy at having so easily overcome my labour (through the Fathers) as it were by certain steps I had ascended to the highest of things, and I saw from the testimony of the Scripture and the Fathers, that the Scripture alone and one was sufficient and that it had no need of human wit to be patched up. I therefore firmly placed my foot on the Scripture alone, being sufficient, without any human addition. If now your genius should be angry with me, let him be angry with the Scripture and the holy Fathers, who even against my will have brought me hither. But here is a hedge between a rock and a holy place. Immediately this occurs to me: Faith to you alone? The Scripture is veiled by many mysteries, from the Fathers you will receive the sense of the Scripture. And again from the other side a stronger ram strikes me with this bellow: The same spirit has the Scripture, which from its beginning, though therefore we should only bestow our care on those. For it is certain that the primitive Church did not read Thomas, not Scotus, not Antoninus, not Augustine. But Augustine approved his understanding of the Scripture according to his own words: There is no place in the Scripture so obscure that it may not be explained in another place. And whenever the Fathers are in opposition to one another, they run to the Scriptures, surely as to the light; for the obscure is to be demonstrated by the more known. If the Scripture were so obscure that it could not be understood without Augustine, it would be more obscure than Augustine's writings. "But if this be admitted, it must be conceded that the holy Fathers have done nothing else in their commentaries than, while they prove their own by the Scriptures, to prove the more known by the more obscure"; but "who is so mad?" Would the Holy Spirit not be understood and only flow to those who are wise and rabbis? But here Christ cries out: "I thank thee, O Father, Lord of Heaven and earth, because thou hast hid these things from the wise and prudent, and hast revealed them unto babes." And Tertullian says: "This is the material of secular wisdom, rash interpretation of the divine disposition. Indeed heresies are instigated by philosophy." "He was in Athens" the Apostle [Acts 17, 16ff] and so forth. And would that I could attribute all these to you! Therefore it is the true saying of the Prophet: "The declaration, or opening of thy words giveth light, and giveth understanding to the simple" [Psalm 119, 130]. Read here the alphabetical Psalm 118 and you will find something wonderful concerning this matter. Again it is written in 1 John 2 [27]: "And ye need not that any man teach you; but as the same anointing teacheth you of all things, and is truth, and is no lie, and even as it hath taught you, ye shall abide in him." Where you hear that understanding is given to the Spirit, which is also promised in Jeremiah 31 [33-34], to which Christ agrees in John 6 [43]: "All shall be taught of God." So also Paul: "But we have not received the spirit of the world, but the Spirit which is of God, that we might know the things which are freely given to us of God. Which things also we speak, not in the words which man's wisdom teacheth, but which the Holy Ghost teacheth, comparing spiritual things with spiritual" [1 Cor 2, 12-13] etc. But who dares to deny the Spirit to believers? That would be to accuse Christ of falsehood: Matthew 7 [7ff], Mark 11 [24ff]. Therefore the Scripture is to be interpreted in its proper sense, that is, in the sense in which it was written, even with your decrees. For if this is not allowed, why was it allowed to Augustine, with no other privilege bestowed upon him, and baptized with us in one baptism, and endowed with one spirit with us? But if it was allowed to Augustine, who is so audacious as not to will that we each one should prophesy, when Paul wills that all should speak, so that there is judgement among them that sit [1 Cor 14, 29]? You yourself know that no one interprets the Scriptures better than the Spirit itself which has sent them forth. Do you then distrust God promising the Spirit? But what is this distrust?

seg.output: I continue; here I rejoiced with the fruit of palms, as if I had overcome so easily through the labor of the fathers, as if I had risen through certain steps to the highest of things, and I saw from the testimony of Scripture and of the fathers that only Scripture is sufficient and that it needs no help of human wit to make it whole. Therefore, firmly fixed on the ground, I followed only Scripture, being sufficient, without any human addition. If now your genius wanted to be angry, come, let it be angry at Scripture and the holy fathers, who even dragged me here unwillingly. But here, too, there is a division between the stone and the sacred herb. Immediately I am confronted with this: to you alone faith? Scripture is veiled in many mysteries; you will receive the sense of Scripture from the fathers. On the other hand a stronger ram shakes me with this bellowing: The same spirit Scripture has from its beginning, although we must, therefore, give our attention to them only. For it is clear that the primitive Church did not read Thomas, nor Scotus, nor Anthony, nor Augustine. But Augustine approved his own understanding from Scripture according to his own word: There is no place in Scripture so obscure that it is not explained in another place. And whenever the fathers are in disagreement, they refer to Scripture, certainly as to light; for the more obscure must be demonstrated by the more known. If, however, Scripture were so obscure that it could not be understood without Augustine, it would be more hidden than Augustine's writings. "Assuming this, I concede that the holy fathers did nothing more in their commentaries than, while they prove their own things from Scripture, to prove the more known by the more unknown"; but "who is so insane?" Or does not the Holy Spirit wish to be understood and only to flow into those who are wise and rabbis? But here Christ cries out: "I thank you, Father, Lord of heaven and earth, that you have hidden these things from the wise and prudent, and revealed them to babes." And Tertullian says: "This is the material of secular wisdom, rashly interpreting the disposition of Divine Nature. Indeed, even heresies are suborned by philosophy." "He was at Athens" [Acts 17:16ff] and so on. And would that I could ascribe all this to you! Therefore the prophet's sentence is most true: "The opening of thy words gives light and understanding to the simple" [Ps 119:130]. Read here the alphabetic Psalm 118 and you will find marvelous things about this. Again, it is written in 1 John 2 [27]: "And you have no need that any man teach you; but as the same anointing teaches you of all things, and is truth, and is no lie, and even as it has taught you, abide in it." Where do you hear that understanding is given to the spirit, which is also promised in Jeremiah 31 [33-34], to which Christ agrees in John 6 [43]: "All shall be taught of God." seg.input: Continuo ego; hic veluti palmarum fructu reperto exultabam gaudio, quod laboribus tam facile superatis (per patres) veluti per gradus quospiam in rerum summam transcenderam, et vidi ex testimonio scripturae et patrum solam scripturam et unicam esse sufficientem et quae humano ingenio, ut sarciatur, minime indigeat. Pede igitur fixo tenui solam scripturam esse sequendam, utpote suffitientem, absque ulla adiectione humana. Si nunc mihi irasci vellet genius tuus, age, irascatur scripturae et sanctis patribus, qui huc etiam quasi nolentem detrusere. Ceterum et hic inter saxum et sacrum herebam. Occurrit ilico: tibi soli fides? Scriptura multis est obvelata misteriis, ex patribus accipies scripturae sensum. Ac rursum ex adversa parte fortior mihi aries haec concutit hoc fragrore: eundem nimirum habet spiritum scriptura, quem a sui principio, licet igitur solis iis nos quoque operam collocare. Hoc enim constat primitivam ecclesiam non legisse Thomam, non Scotum, non Anthoninum, non Augustinum. Augustinum vero suam probasse intelligentiam ex scripturis iuxta verbum suum: Nullus est locus in scriptura tam obscurus, quin in alio loco explicetur. Et quoties invicem pugnant patres, ad scripturas concurrunt, certe ceu ad lucem; nam debent ignotiora per notiora demonstrari. Si vero tam obscura foret scriptura, ut sine Augustino intelligi non posset, obtectior esset Augustini scriptis. «Hoc autem admisso concedendum sanctos patres commentariis suis aliud non fecisse quam, dum sua probant scripturis, notiora probarint per ignotiora»; sed «quis ita insaniat»? An noluit spiritus sanctus intelligi et iis solum illabi, qui sapientes sunt et rabbini? Verum hic clamat Christus: «Gratias ago tibi, pater, domine coeli et terrae, quod absconderis haec a sapientibus et prudentibus, et revelaveris ea parvulis.» Et Tertullianus ait: «Ea est materia sapientiae secularis, temeraria interpraes divinae naturae dispositionis. Ipse denique haereses a phylosophia subornantur». «Fuerat Athenis» apostolus [Apg 17,16ff] et cetera. Et utinam tibi omnia ea adscribere possem! Est ergo verissima prophetae sententia: «Declaratio, ostium seu apertum verborum tuorum illuminat et intellectum dat parvulis» [Ps 119,130]. Lege hic Psalmum alphabeticum 118 et mira de hac re invenies. Rursus I. Ioan. 2 [27] scribitur: «Et non necesse habetis, ut quisquam doceat vos, sed sicut ipsa unctio docet vos de omnibus, et verax est et non mendatium, et sicut docuit vos, manete in ea.» Ubi audis spiritui dari intelligentiam, id, quod etiam promissum est Hieremie 31 [33-34], cui adsentitur Christus Ioan. 6 [43]: «Erunt omnes docti a deo.» Ita et Paulus: «Nos vero non spiritum mundi accepimus, sed spiritum, qui ex deo est, ut sciamus quae a Christo donata sint nobis. Si enim hoc non licet, Augustino cur licuit interim nullo alio privilegio dotato et in uno baptizmate nobiscum baptizato unoque nobiscum spiritu potato? Si vero Augustino licuit, quis tam audax, qui prophetari nos singulos nolit, interim cum Paulus omnes loqui velit, ita ut apud sedentes iuditium sit [1Kor 14,29]? Novisti ipse neminem scripturas rectius interpraetari quam spiritum ipsum, qui easdem edidit. Tu ne ergo diffidis deo promittenti spiritum? At quae haec diffidentia? Ubi christianus animus, ubi promissiones, ubi lavacrum regenerationis? - Ego cum Augustino dico in Ioannem tracta. 16, quoties difficilior locus incidit: «Accipite, charissimi, quid hic sentiam sine praeiuditio, si vos melius aliquid senseritis. seg.output: What can I say about councils? They have often erred. Does not the council of Milevis, concerning free will, grace, sin and merit, agree with the new (as they call it) doctrine of our times? Does not the African Synod defend the Lutheran (as they say) doctrine of the primacy of Peter? What shall we say here? Do these two things conflict with the rest? If they conflict, it is necessary that one of them erred; if they agree, whence comes our dissension? Or how shall this question be ended? Whence shall error be discerned? From the bishops? From the doctors? But could they too have erred? Anastasius and Liberius were Roman Pontiffs, and they were Arians. See also what Cyprian of Carthage had determined concerning the rebaptizing of heretics with their own bishops. But if we rely upon them alone, we reject the sacred Scriptures. But what then shall be more uncertain than Christianity? But the bishops of the ancient councils opposed the Scriptures. Consider also the spirit of the Nicene Synod when the celibacy of the presbyters was treated with Paphnutius alone objecting (Distinctio 31. canon. Nicena.), where, when the Emperor burned books! Nor is this the last among the first councils, so what shall I say of the others? - Now what is more vain than custom, and also the multitude? By custom, idolatry might be set up anew among us, by the multitude, Christ might be rebuked for a liar, Elijah and Micah might be overcome [1 Kings 19,10; 22,13ff], the apostles might be despised [Acts 2,13]. Therefore, when the decrees shone forth from the fathers, while they themselves disagreed among each other, referred to the Scriptures and would not believe either themselves or their own interpretations, "immediately" I, with Paul, "did not yield to flesh and blood" [Gal 1,16], I sought the Spirit from the Lord, changed my mind and went to the Scriptures. Now I turn them, I proclaim them to the public, meanwhile with great hatred of some, although I say with Paul: "If I still pleased men, I would not be the servant of Christ" [Gal 1,10].

Now, in the name of Christ, put on judgment and pronounce it to us. Our age, and the same study, once held us both; do you think you now act more wisely? You adhere to decrees, but I to scriptures quickly. Not that I have utterly rejected decrees, unless where they are not consonant to scriptures. That which I have not so pertinaciously proposed at present, that I will not be advised by you, or by any other, to make it better; all things are possible to old friendship! Command, bid, enjoin, teach, exhort, confute, pluck up; you are a friend, you shall remain a friend. At least, if I think amiss, let me know it, and proceed no further in hatred; but if this variety or change of my understanding produces dissention, turn it in your mind, what space there is between divine and human, view and consider what is done by our bishops. And oh that you would come to our house, we should then discourse more fully of these and other things, which you could not do more acceptably. Command, enjoin, order, teach, exhort, confute, pull to pieces; you are a friend, you shall remain a friend. At least, if I think amiss, tell it us, and proceed no farther in your enmities; and if this variety or change of my wit produces any division, consider you within yourself, how great a distance there is between divine and human; you see and consider what is done by our bishops. And, oh that you would but come to our college, we should then discourse of these and several other matters in a more plentiful way, which you could not do more obligingly. Peradventure then might be restored the restoring of our friendship, if it be now broken, which I cannot be induced to believe; though all things may be effected by a venemous language, and therefore have I at large expressed our mind, to be worthy of a Christian (as we hope) man, lest the vilest lips should heap invidiousness on you. It remains now that the voice of Christ, not mine, address you as you depart, sounding, He that believeth on me, believeth not on me, but on him that sent me; and he that seeth me, seeth him that sent me. I am come a light into the world, that whosoever believeth on me should not abide in darkness. And if any man hear my words, and believe not, I judge him not; for I came not to judge the world, but to save the world.

Atque utinam nostras aedes adires, dissereremus tum pluribus de hisce et aliis rebus compluribus, quo et nihil gratius facere posses. seg.output: Now, in the name of Christ, make ready your judgement and pronounce it upon us. The same age, the same study, once had both of us; do you now think to act more wisely? You adhere to decrees, but I to the scriptures quickly. Not that I do altogether reject decrees, unless in so far as they disagree with the scriptures. That which I have not so pertinaciously propounded in the present instance, as not to be content that it may be amended by you or by some other, learned man; all things are possible to old friendship! Command, bid, enjoin, teach, exhort, confute, pull up by the roots: you are a friend, you shall remain a friend. At least, if I err, inform me of it, and cease not to nourish hatred; and if this variety or vicissitude of my genius produces a schism, consider within yourself what space there is between divine and human; behold and consider what is done by our bishops. And how I wish you would come to our meeting-place, that we might discourse more largely of these, and many other matters; so might you do nothing more acceptable. Perchance, then, some agreement might be entered into for restoring our friendship, if it be indeed broken; which I cannot be induced to believe; although all things are possible to a poisonous tongue; and therefore we have explained our minds in more extended language, lest any of the most filthy lips should bring a charge against you. Now, let not my voice, but Christ's, address you as you depart, sounding: “He that believeth on me, believeth not on me, but on Him that sent me; and he that seeth me, seeth Him that sent me. I am come a light into the world, that whosoever believeth on me should not abide in darkness. And if any man hear my words, and believe not, I judge him not; for I came not to judge the world, but to save the world. He that rejecteth me, and receiveth not my words, hath one that judgeth him; the word that I have spoken, the same shall judge him in the last day. For I have not spoken of myself; but the Father which sent me, He gave me a commandment, what I should say, and what I should speak. And I know that His commandment is life everlasting. Whatsoever I speak therefore, even as the Father said unto me, so I speak.”

seg.output: Now, in the name of Christ, take up the challenge and give us your judgment. We used to have the same age and same interests, do you think you can act wiser now? You adhere to the decrees, I to the Scriptures. I'm not denying the decrees, only when they don't agree with the Scriptures. What I don't propose so stubbornly nowadays is that the tradition, which is better taught by you or someone else, should be changed; friendship can do anything! Command, order, instruct, teach, exhort, refute, pull down; you are a friend, you will remain a friend. At least, if I think wrong, let me know and don't keep going on with the hatred; likewise, if this diversity or variation of my mind causes discord, consider for yourself how much space there is between the divine and the human, and see for yourself what our bishops are doing. And if only you could come to our house, we would discuss more of these and many other things, where nothing would be more satisfying. Perhaps, then, of restoring our friendship, if it has been ruined, which I cannot be induced to think; although, all that can be done with a poisonous tongue and therefore we have explained our mind, worthy of a Christian (as we hope), with more words, so that no filthy lips among you may heap up envy. Now, the voice of Christ, not mine, may take leave of you, sounding: “He who believes in me, does not believe in me but in him who sent me; and he who sees me, sees him who sent me. I have come as a light into the world, that whoever believes in me should not remain in darkness. And if anyone hears my words and does not believe them, I do not judge him; for I did not come to judge the world but to save the world. He who rejects me and does not receive my words, has one who judges him; the word that I have spoken, the same shall judge him in the last day. For I have not spoken of myself, but the Father who sent me gave me a commandment as to what I should say and speak. And I know that His commandment is eternal life. Therefore, what I speak, just as the Father has told me, so I speak.” Farewell in Christ Jesus and let us all pray for that peaceful king, may he inspire us with charity, bestow true peace and be the defender of a just cause. From our monastery of Cappell, the day before the Kalends of December, in the year of the Redemption of the world 1523.

seg.output: What shall I say about councils? They have often erred. Does not the Council of Mileve agree with the new (as they call it) doctrine of our times concerning free will, grace, sin, and merit? Does not the African Synod uphold the Lutheran (as they say) doctrine concerning the primacy of Peter? What are we to say here? Do these two conflict with the rest? If they do, it is necessary that one of them has erred; if they agree, where then is our disagreement? Or how is this question to be ended? From where can error be discerned? From bishops? From doctors? But could they too have erred? Anastasius and Liberius were Roman pontiffs, yet they were Arians. See also, what was established by Cyprian of Carthage concerning heretics to be rebaptized with their own bishops. Moreover, if we depend on them entirely, we reject the Sacred Scriptures. But what can be more uncertain for Christianity? But the bishops of the ancient councils have fought against the Scriptures. Consider the Nicene Synod, where the spirit was, when the celibacy of the presbyters was discussed, with only one Paphnutius protesting (Distinction 31 of the Nicene Canons), where Caesar was burning books! This is not the last thing to be considered among the first councils, so what shall I say about the others? Now what is more vain than custom, and also the multitude? By custom, idolatry could be re-established among us, Christ could be reproved by the multitude as a liar, Elijah and Micah could be overcome [1 Kön 19,10; 22,13ff], and the apostles contemned [Apg 2,13]. Therefore, when the decrees of the fathers were almost shining, but the fathers disagreed among themselves, and referred to the Scriptures and would not believe either themselves or their interpretations, "immediately" I, with Paul, "did not consent to flesh and blood" [Gal 1,16], I asked for the Spirit from the Lord, changed my mind, and went to the Scriptures. I now translate them, I proclaim them to the public, meanwhile, with the great hatred of some, although I say with Paul: "If I were still pleasing to men, I would not be a servant of Christ" [Gal 1,10].

seg.output:
What should I say about the decisions? They have often gone wrong. Does not the decision of the Council of Milevis agree with the new (as they call it) doctrine of our times on free will, grace, sin and merit? Does not the African Synod defend the primacy of Peter according to the Lutheran (as they say) doctrine? What shall we say about this? Do these not conflict with the rest? If so, necessarily one of them must have gone wrong; if they agree, whence comes our discord? Or how shall this question be settled? Whence shall the error be discerned? From the bishops? From the doctors? But could not they also have erred? Anastasius and Liberius were Roman pontiffs, and Arians. See also what Cyprian of Carthage determined concerning the rebaptizing of heretics with their own bishops. Nay, if we hang upon them altogether, we reject the sacred Scriptures. But what could be more uncertain than Christianity? But the bishops of the ancient decisions opposed the Scriptures. Consider the spirit of the Nicene Synod when it treated of the celibacy of the presbyters, with one Paphnutius only dissenting (Distinct. 31, Can. Nicen.). When Caesar burnt the books! Neither do we reckon this as the least among the first decisions; what then shall I say of the rest? What is more vain than custom, yea, and multitude? By custom, idolatry might be again set up among us; by multitude, Christ might be reproached as a deceiver, Elias and Michaas overcome [1Kön 19,10; 22,13ff], the apostles despised [Apg 2,13]. Therefore, when the decrees almost glittered, and the fathers disagreed among themselves, referred the decision to the Scriptures, and would not believe either themselves or their own interpretations, "I immediately," as I said with Paul, "gave not place to the flesh and blood" [Gal 1,16], I sought the spirit from the Lord, I changed my mind, and I went to the Scriptures. I now turn them, I publish them to the people, in the meanwhile with the great hatred of some, although I say with Paul: "If I pleased men, I should not be the servant of Christ" [Gal 1,10]. In the meanwhile, thou hast that I will not give place to the flesh and blood, that I will not sow heresies, that is, sects, nor introduce new doctrines, but that I will trust to the spirit, study concord, and recall the old evangelical and apostolic doctrine; thou hast what has drawn me into this business, thou hast the most holy fathers of my institution for guides, thou hast my mind thirsting after nothing but Christ and the good of the people, and this I call to be my witness before my own conscience, Jesus Christ the just.
Now in the name of Christ pronounce the judgment upon us. Now in the name of Christ pronounce the judgment upon us. seg.output: Now, in the name of Christ, take up your judgement and declare it unto us. We both once had the same age and the same enthusiasm, do you now think that you act more wisely? You adhere to the decrees, and I to the scriptures quickly. Not that I totally reject the decrees, except where they do not agree with the scriptures. seg.output: Now, in the name of Christ, take up the challenge and give us your judgement.We have both had the same age and the same interests at some point, do you think you are acting more wisely now? You adhere to the decrees, while I to the scriptures. Not that I totally reject the decrees, unless they are not in accordance with the scriptures. That which I have not so obstinately proposed at present, that I should not wish for any wise man, either you or another, to change the established order, all this can be done through the power of old friendship! Command, order, teach, exhort, refute, overturn; you are a friend, you will remain a friend. At least, if I am mistaken, let me know and do not proceed any further with hatred; but if this diversity or change of my mind produces disagreement, you yourself consider how great a distance there is between divine and human, you yourself see and consider what is done by our bishops. And how I wish you would visit our house, then we could discuss many things, and you could do nothing more pleasant. Perhaps then our friendship, if it has been destroyed, might be restored; though I cannot be induced to believe it, all can be done through a poisonous tongue, and thus we have explained to you in more words the sentiments of our mind, which we hope is worthy of a Christian man, lest the most loathsome lips might heap up envy against you. Now that you are departing, let not my voice, but the voice of Christ, address you, saying: "He that believeth on me, believeth not on me, but on him that sent me.And he that seeth me seeth him that sent me.I am come a light into the world, that whosoever believeth on me should not abide in darkness.And if any man hear my words, and believe not, I judge him not: for I came not to judge the world, but to save the world.He that rejecteth me, and receiveth not my words, hath one that judgeth him: the word that I have spoken, the same shall judge him in the last day.For I have not spoken of myself; but the Father which sent me, he gave me a commandment, what I should say, and what I should speak.And I know that his commandment is life everlasting: whatsoever I speak therefore, even as the Father said unto me, so I speak." Farewell in Christ Jesus, and let us jointly pray for the peaceful King, that he may inspire us with charity, grant us true peace and be Himself the defender of a just cause. From our monastery of Cappell, the 30th of November in the year of the redemption of the world 1523.
